_exec_summary.SummaryText:
Chlorine:

1.  Chlorine gas is used in water treatment process for the 
   purpose of disinfecting the effluent.  In those cases where    
   chlorine gas is supplied for one ton chlorine containers (i.e. 
   more than 1,500 lbs. is present on site)) the chlorine supply 
   system must comply with the requirements of 29 CFR 1910.119 - 
   Process Safety Management of Highly Hazardous Chemicals.  The 
   purpose of this document is to meet the requirements for a 
   written compilation of Process Safety Information, and to  
   record the results of the recently completed Process Hazards 
   Analysis.  The process includes the Chlorine Supply and 
   distribution system from the ton cylinders up to the point the 
   chlorinated effluent is dispersed into the Contact Chamber, 
   where the chlorine is dissolved.  At this point, the potential 
   for a release of highly hazardous material as defined by OSHA 
   does not exist.

2.  This document provides guidelines to ensure the health and 
   safety of our employees and the general public where potential 
   releases of chlorine may occur when working with one ton    
   chlorine cylinders. The provision of these guidelines will be  
   implemented by facility personnel during routine maintenance   
   and when there is an unusual occurrence that could threaten 
   human health, the environment and property.  This document 
   will be reviewed and updated as needed, and at least annually.

II.  Site description

1.  The Surface Water Plant and Ground Water Plant provides 
   drinking water for approximately 19,000 people.  

2.  At the Surface Water Treatment Plant the chlorine supply and 
   finished water pumps are on-site and located approximately 100 
   yards from the plant office.  The ton containers and 
   associated equipment is located at the southeast corner of the 
   site on a cement pad, outdoors, but roofed to protect 
   cylinders from direct sunlight.  Plant layout is depicted in 
   Figure 5. At the

Ground Water Treatment Plant the ton 
   cylinders and associated equipment are located on the 
   southwest corner of the site on a cement pad, roofed and 
   partially covered, protected from sunlight and located 
   approximately 25 yards from the plant office.  At the Waste 
   Water Treatment Plant the ton containers and associated 
   equipment are located at the north end of the Plant 
   approximately 50 yards from the office.   

III. Employee Participation

1. Two operators, who are at least C level certified by the 
   Department of Environmental Protection, are required to be 
   present at all times whenever connecting or disconnecting one 
   ton chlorine cylinders.  Routine removal and installation of 
   one-ton chlorine cylinders shall take place only during normal 
   working hours (7:00AM to 3:00PM- Monday to Friday). The 
   secondary operator will perform the task and the shift 
   operator is designated the backup should an emergency arise.
                                
2.  The shift operator will also assist in the transporting of  
   empty and full cylinders to their stations with the cylinder 
   covers (bonnets) in place.  A shift operator will supervise 
   the tasks of disconnecting and reconnecting of chlorine 
   cylinders.  This requires the operator actually performing the 
   disconnecting and reconnecting tasks and breathing with SCBA 
   before beginning and during this work. The operator will stand 
   by upwind, observing work being performed from a safe distance 
   within visual contact and ready to assist should an emergency 
   arise.  This requires that a SCBA be worn, but is not required 
   to have face mask connected unless assisting in the actual 
   disconnecting or reconnecting of chlorine cylinders. Both 
   operators will work together in moving of empty cylinders and 
   their replacement with full ones on the scales.  A SCBA must 
   be worn but masks does not have to be donned during these 
   operations.  E

nsure that cylinder covers are installed during 
   movement of chlorine cylinders.


IV.  Material Properties and Hazards

1. General.  Chlorine is one of the chemical elements. It is a    
   member of the halogen (or salt-forming group) along with 
   fluorine, bromine, iodine and astatine.  Chlorine occurs 
   naturally only in a combined state, primarily  with sodium as  
   salt (NaCl).  As an element, the atomic symbol is Cl, its 
   atomic weight is 35.453, and the atomic number is 17. The 
   molecular symbol is Cl2 and the molecular weight is 70.906.  
   It is manufactured predominately by electrolytic cell process  
   and is widely used for treating municipal and industrial water 
   supplies. 

  a. Chlorine gas is a severe respiratory irritant, and chlorine 
   liquid is irritating to the skin.  The gas has a pungent odor 
   detectable at concentrations of less than 1 ppm.  A few 
   breaths of air with a concentration of 100 ppm of Chlorine is 
   likely to be fatal.  The following exposure limits apply:  

    Permissible Exposure Limit (PEL) is 1 ppm (ceiling) and time 
    weighted Average (TWA) is 3mg/m3 (ceiling).


  b. Chlorine has the following physical and chemical 
    characteristics:

   (1) It is colorless in small amounts.
   (2) It is a liquid only if pressurized or at very
      low temperatures.
   (3)It has an expansion rate of 457 to 1, or, simply
      stated, 1 part of liquid evaporates to 457 parts
      of gas.
   (4) It is 2.5 times heavier than air in the gaseous
       state.
   (5) It is not flammable, however, it supports
       combustion.
   (6) It reacts violently with hydrocarbons and other
       volatile substances.
   (7) It will cause most metals to burn at elevated
       temperatures.
   (8) It is only slightly soluble in water.
   (9) It reacts with water (moisture) to produce
       hydrochloric acid (HCl) and hypochlorous acid
       (HOCl).

A material safety data sheet is included in appendix C.

2.  Reacti

vity and Incompatibility.  Chlorine is a strong         
    oxidizer and will react chemically with many substances,  
    often with the evolution of heat.  At temperatures above  
    approximately 150' F, chlorine reacts vigorously with many 
    metals, including steel.  

    Chlorine systems should be kept as dry as possible.  Chlorine 
    reacts with water evolving heat and producing a corrosive 
    acidic solution.  In the event of a leak, water sprays should 
    not be used since the resulting corrosion will worsen the 
    leak. Chlorine gas will react with ammonia gas to produce a 
    visible cloud of ammonia chloride.  This property is used for 
    leak checking by squirting ammonia gas from the vapor space 
    above an ammonium hydroxide solution over any suspected 
    leakage areas while looking for a white plume.





V.   Process Technology

1.   Process Flow Diagram.    A simplified process flow
    diagram of a typical chlorinator system using one-ton chorine
    cylinders is shown in Appendix D. The process description 
    below refers to this diagram.

2.   Process Description.

  a. Chlorine is injected in the filter effluent for 
    disinfection.  At the WTP/WWTP gaseous chlorine is     
    continuously fed to the Chlorine Contact Chamber to achieve a 
    1.0 to 10.0 ppm residual total chlorine level in the 
    effluent.Typically, about 100 pounds per day of chlorine is 
    used for every 700,000 gallons of effluent at the Water 
    Plants (Surface and Ground) and 60 to 70 pounds for every 
    600,000 gallons of effluent at the Waste Water Treatment 
    Plant.
  
  b. Four one ton gas/liquid chlorine containers are fabricated
    to DOT specifications as large steel welded tanks or cylin
    ders.  The average container is about 30 inches in outside 
    diameter and about 82 inches in length.  Average tare weight 
    is 1500 pounds, average gross weight is about 3,500 pounds, 
    leaving 2,000 pounds net weight.  Each end of

a difuser.  The feed system from the 
    container to the ejector is operated under vacuum, so any 
    small leaks pull in air instead of releasing chlorine.

  f. The chlorinator is equipped with a small 25 watt heater 
    element.  As chlorine is drawn into the chlorinator from the 
    one-ton container, it is deflected down into a drip leg where 
    any liquid chlorine is vaporized, permitting only gas to 
    enter the regulating portion of the chlorinator.

  g. A vent valve with plastic tubing is provided with the chlo
    rinator unit.  The vent tube is routed to vent to the 
    atmosphere.  Also provided with the chlorinator is a chlorine 
    supply indicator.  A green indication represents the presence 
    of chlorine and a red indication represents a loss of 
    chlorine supply and that the inlet safety valve is closed.

  h. Appendix E shows vendor details of the chlorinator.  Water, 
    at about 40 to 60 psig pressure, from a two inch supply line 
    is piped to the ejector. This circuit contains a shutoff 
    valve, and pressure gauge.  As this water flows through the 
    ejector at high velocity, it creates a vacuum in the chlorine 
    feed tubing which opens a spring-loaded check valve contained 
    in the ejector assembly. When the check valve at the ejector 
    opens this permits the vacuum to travel back through the 
    plastic vacuum tubing to the chlorinator.  This causes the 
    inlet safety valve in the chlorinator to open, initiating 
    chlorine gas flow.  A filter located in the chlorinator 
    removes any foreign material from the gas.  A spring-opposed 
    diaphragm regulates the vacuum at this point to allow the gas 
    to pass through a rotameter.  A manual feed rate control 
    valve is provided to regulate the chlorine gas flow to the 
    ejector.  From the ejector, the gas is thoroughly mixed with 
    water and carried through schedule eighty (80) PVC pipe to 
    the diffuser located in the Chlorine Contact

a ton container 
    is concave, with one end equipped with two valves protected 
    by a removal bonnet housing.  The valves are connected to 
    eduction pipes located inside the container. The valves must 
    be aligned vertically so that the upper valve is used to 
    withdraw gaseous chlorine from above the liquid level in the 
    container.  The lower valve is for liquid withdrawal and is 
    not to be used.

  c. There are six to eight fusible metal plugs in a one ton 
    container, three to four in each end.  These serve as an   
    over-pressure relief device.  The internal pressure of the 
    container is equal to the vapor pressure of liquid chlorine 
    which varies with ambient temperature.  A container exposed 
    to ambient temperatures of 0 degrees to 100 degrees will have 
    an internal pressure ranging from 14 psig to 143 psig.  In 
    the event of a fire or overheating, at a temperature of about 
    160 degrees and a resulting vapor pressure of approximately 
    320 psig, the fusible plugs will melt and release the 
    contents of the container to the atmosphere. The DOT 
    Hydrostatic pressure specification of the container is 500 
    psig.


  d. Chlorine container trunnions are used for supporting and 
    spacing the containers and allowing for easy rotation of the 
    containers to correctly position the outlet valves.

  e. Because chlorine poses a serious health risk if released to 
    the atmosphere, chlorine is fed from the one-ton containers 
    through a fail-safe device called a chlorinator.  A chlori
    nator system includes two main components, a vacuum regulator 
    which mounts directly to the upper gas valve of the one-ton 
    chlorine container by means of a lead gasket positive yoke 
    assembly, and an ejector which uses effluent flow to create 
    the necessary vacuum. From the ejector the chlorine gas mixes 
    with the effluent before being injected into the chlorine 
    contact chamber through

Chamber for 
    final dispensing of the chlorinated solution.


3. Plant Specific Characteristics.  The Okeechobee Surface Water  
    Treatment Plant, Ground Water Treatment Plant and Waste Water 
    Treatment Plant differ from the general description as shown  
    in Appendix D, a schematic of a chlorine feed system.         
    Specifically, Two one-ton cylinders are interconnected by a   
    vacuum operated switch over valve which feeds to the ejector. 
    Chlorinated effluent can then be fed into an intermediate     
    pumping station then pumped to a 1.5 million gallon contact   
    chamber.  A copy of the instruction manual for Capital      
    Controls Advance` 200 Series Gas Feeders is located in      
    Appendix E.  A copy of the instruction manual for Capital     
    Controls Automatic Switch over Module, Vacuum Type, is      
    located in Appendix E.  A copy of the instruction manual for  
    Capital Controls Advance` Gas Feeder (Ton Mounted) is located 
    in Appendix E.


Ammonia:

1.  Ammonia gas is used in water treatment process for the 
   purpose of THM control in the effluent.  In those cases 
   where Ammonia gas is supplied for 1000 gallon containers 
   (i.e.more than 4000 lbs. is present on site)) the Ammonia 
   supply system must comply with the requirements of 29 CFR
   1910.119 -Process Safety Management of Highly Hazardous 
   Chemicals. The purpose of this document is to meet the 
   requirements for a written compilation of Process Safety 
   Information, and to record the results of the recently 
   completed Process Hazards Analysis.  The process includes 
   the Ammonia Supply and distribution system from the 1000 lb.
   cylinders up to the point the chlorinated effluent is 
   dispersed into the Contact Chamber where the Ammonia is 
   dissolved.  At this point, the potential for a release of 
   highly hazardous material as defined by OSHA does not exist.

2.  This document provides guidelines to ensure the health

and 
   safety of our employees and the general public where potential 
   releases of Ammonia may occur when working with one thousand    
   gallon cylinders. The provision of these guidelines will be  
   implemented by facility personnel during routine maintenance   
   and when there is an unusual occurrence that could threaten 
   human health, the environment and property.  This document 
   will be reviewed and updated as needed, and at least annually.

II.  Site description

1.  The Surface Water Plant and Ground Water Plant provides 
   drinking water for approximately 19,000 people.  

2.  At the Surface Water Treatment Plant the Ammonia supply and 
   finished water pumps are on-site and located approximately 100 
   yards from the plant office.  The 1,000 gallon containers and 
   associated equipment is located at the southwest corner of the 
   site on a cement pad, outdoors, but roofed to protect 
   cylinders from direct sunlight.  Plant layout is depicted in 
   Figure 5. At the Ground Water Treatment Plant the 1,000 gal. 
   cylinders and associated equipment are located on the 
   southwest corner of the site on a cement pad, roofed and 
   partially covered, protected from sunlight and located 
   approximately 25 yards from the plant office.     

III. Employee Participation

1. Two operators, who are at least C level certified by the 
   Department of Environmental Protection, are required to be 
   present at all times whenever connecting or disconnecting lines 
   on any part of the cylinders.  Routine removal and installation
   of regulator units and piping shall take place only during 
   normal working hours (7:00AM to 3:00PM- Monday to Friday).The 
   secondary operator will perform the task and the shift 
   operator is designated the backup should an emergency arise.
                                
2  A shift operator will supervise and assist in closing valves, 
   andthe tasks of disconnecting regulators and any piping 
   conne

cted to cylinders.  This requires the operator actually 
   performing the disconnecting and reconnecting tasks and 
   breathing with SCBA before beginning and during this work. 
   The shift operator will stand by upwind, observing work being 
   performed from a safe distance within visual contact and ready
   to assist should an emergency arise.  This requires that a SCBA
   be worn, and to  have face mask connected and assisting in the 
   actual disconnecting or reconnecting of regulators and piping 
   if needed. Both operators will work together concerning this 
   task.  A SCBA must be worn and masks  have to be donned during 
   these operations.  
   


IV.  Material Properties and Hazards

1. Ammonia can be supplied for water treatment applications in
   three different forms: as a pure liquid (anhydrous ammonia),
   dissolved in water(aquaeous ammonia), and as a dry ammonium
   salt. At normal temperatures and pressures, anhydrous ammonia
   (>99 percent NH3)is a gas. However, anhydrous can be easily 
   liquified and it is commonly stored and transported in liquid
   form in pressurized containers very similar to chlorine 
   cylinders.At atmospheric pressure, liquid anhydrous ammonia 
   has a density of 42.6 lb/ft3, approximately two thirds that 
   of water.
 
   Molecular weight=17.03, 
   Boiling point= -280f (-33.40 c), 
   Freezingpoint= -107.90f (-77.70c)

  a. Ammonia gas is a severe respiratory irritant, and Ammonia 
   liquid is irritating to the skin.   
   The following exposure limits apply:  

    Permissible Exposure Limit (PEL) is 50 ppm (ceiling) and time 
    weighted Average (TWA) is 25 ppm (ceiling).


  b. Ammonia has the following physical and chemical 
    characteristics:

   (1) It is colorless in small amounts.
   (2) It is a liquid only if pressurized or at very
       low temperatures.
   (3) Can cause severe burns, eye and lung injuries.
   (4) Skin and respiratory related diseases aggravated by
       exposure.
   (5) Extreme exposure (5000ppm) can cause immediate death 
       from spasm, inflamation or Edema of larynx.


     A material safety data sheet is included in appendix C.


2.  Reactivity and Incompatibility.  

    Avoid mixing with sulfuric acid or other strong mineral acids.
    Avoid mixing with Hypochlorites (chlorine bleach) or other
    halogens and sodium hydroxide. Avoid contact with galvanized
    surfaces,copper,brass,bronze,aluminum alloys,mercury,gold,
    silver, and strong oxidizers. Avoid heating. 




V.  Process Technology

1.  Process Flow Diagram.    A simplified process flow
    diagram of a typical Ammonia system  is shown in Appendix D.
    The process description below refers to this diagram.

2.  Process Description.

    Ammonia is injected in the filter effluent for THM control
    At the SWTP/GWTP gaseous Ammonia is continuously fed to the
    Chlorine Contact Chamber to achieve a ratio of 3 parts CL2
    to 1 part Ammonia residual in the effluent.Typically, about
    33.3 pounds per day of chlorine is used for every 700,000 
    gallons of effluent at the Water Plants (Surface and Ground).
    
  
    Two one trhousand gallon

gas/liquid containers are fabricated
    to DOT specifications as large steel welded tanks or cylin
    ders. The average container is about 40 inches in outside 
    diameter and about 96 inches in length. Holding a maximum 
    weight of 4,250 lbs.
